awd_titl_txt: Mnemonic Integration of Prefrontal-temporal Lobe Activity during Emotional Memory Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to lay down long-lasting memories of events is crucial for survival. Being able to predict a threat that occurs seconds or minutes after an environmental cue allows for evasive or defensive action. Despite considerable progress towards understanding how memories are formed, many questions remain, such as how the brain learns about events separated in time. This project uses cutting-edge tools in neuroscience to address a previously intractable problem about how brain systems function on a second-by-second basis to link events in memory. This contribution is significant because it is expected to identify key principles of brain function that will advance our understanding of more complex forms of learning and memory. Undergraduate students, including underrepresented groups in science (women and minorities), participate in data collection, analysis, and dissemination. This project also provides an opportunity to develop educational tools to help stimulate interest in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields within the broader community. These tools include an interactive demonstration of neuronal activity and brain stimulation for annual outreach efforts to high schools in the greater Milwaukee, Wisconcin area. 

Nearly all forms of motivated behavior require the association of events that are separated in time, but very little is known about the underlying mechanisms supporting these associations, highlighting a critical gap in the study of memory: how are sensory inputs integrated in memory when they do not overlap in time? The principal investigator recently revealed a causal link between a neural signature of working memory in the prefrontal cortex and the formation of long-term fear memory. The objective of this project is to determine how an auditory cue held in short-term working memory systems within the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus is associated with shock inputs in the amygdala to drive plasticity and adaptive fear responses. With the recent development of optogenetic tools, it is now possible to interrogate the function of discrete patterns of firing in specific neural connections. Here, the investigators leverage this tool in combination with electrophysiology in awake, behaving animals to determine when short-term mnemonic information is integrated with sensory input during memory formation. Given the importance of the prefrontal cortex and the hippocampus for the adaptive use of memory to guide behavior, a hallmark of executive function, determining how mnemonic input from these structures is integrated in downstream brain areas informs the understanding of a broad range of adaptive and maladaptive behaviors.

por.por_cntn:
Linking discrete events in memory requires a distributed network of brain regions devoted to different aspects of experience, such as stimulus properties, the aversive or rewarding value of outcomes, and the spatial and temporal relationships between environmental cues and outcomes. How brain areas work together to form a cohesive memory from these individual components is unclear but determining how information flows between brain areas would help us better understand how episodic memories are formed. Moreover, it would shed light on how certain features of a memory, such as its emotional content, may gain stronger or weaker representation in the resultant memory based on the activity within specific brain connections. Our project sought to determine how direct connections between episodic memory structures - the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex - and an emotional memory structure - the amygdala - support learning about threat-predictive cues (cued fear) and aversive environments (contextual fear). 

 

The key scientific outcomes of our project are two-fold.

 

1) We have dissociated cued and contextual components of a fear memory at the level of network connections supporting memory formation.  Forming a fear memory between a cue and shock or context and shock requires the amygdala.  However, forming a cued fear memory when the cue and shock do not overlap in time requires the prefrontal cortex and the ventral hippocampus. All three structures are necessary for learning that the environment (context) is also predictive of shock. Thus, we sought to determine which connections were critical for conveying cued and temporal information and which were critical for conveying contextual information. Our findings suggest that a convergence of prefrontal and hippocampal inputs in the amygdala is necessary for linking the cue and shock across time and that the ventral hippocampus broadcasts contextual information to other nodes in the learning network to support memory.

 

2) Our results provide novel information about the contribution of the ventral hippocampus to associative memory.  The ventral hippocampus is implicated in fear and anxiety, but little was known about its role in binding events in memory.  In addition to showing that the ventral hippocampus broadcasts contextual information to other nodes in the learning network to support fear memories, we found that its connection to the amygdala shapes the development of cued fear behavior and cue encoding in the amygdala. Cutting off input from the ventral hippocampus slowed the development of the amygdala’s neuronal encoding of fearful events and impaired fear memory. In a separate study, we found that the ventral hippocampal response to aversive events has the capacity to constrain fear to cues and contexts. Together, these distinct patterns of results suggest that the ventral hippocampus can modulate fear memories and fear-related behaviors more broadly through distinct circuits.

 

The project also contributed to the training and professional mentorship of two graduate students and several undergraduate students, many of whom were women or underrepresented minority groups in STEM. These students developed a set of laboratory skills and hypothesis testing skills, applied sophisticated neuroscience techniques to their hypotheses, collected and analyzed behavioral and neural data, and presented their work at local or national conferences. We also provided novel opportunities for high school students in Southeast Wisconsin and surrounding areas to learn more about neuroscience and neuroscience-related careers through annual outreach presentations. Finally, we piloted a new multi-day workshop for underrepresented high school students in Milwaukee that introduced a range of scientific fields of study and coached students through applying critical thinking skills to a pandemic scenario in our Zombie Outbreak event.
